item.description:
Disloyal Royals is a two player card game that uses only standard playing cards and dice. At the beginning of the game, each player is dealt a jack, queen, and king. This is your royal family. The royal family wants to collect riches (diamonds) and bury them (face down) for safe keeping. Throughout the game, players will attempt to dig up their opponent's riches using their shovels (spades). When this doesn't work, they will attack their rival using their clubs (clubs). To protect against clubbings, they will strengthen their defences (hearts). The player with the most buried riches (diamonds) at the end of the game wins.

—description from the designer

The Few and Cursed is a deckbuilding adventure game that takes place in a post-apocalyptic earth where most of the water on the planet has been gone for seventy years. Without water, civilization just halted any progress and stayed pretty much the same...with the exception of the monsters, magic and curses that showed up.

In the game, players take on the role of a curse-chasing bounty hunter looking to make a name for themselves. Players traverse the desert of the Pacific Ocean as they improvise and acquire new cards for their deck on their quest for the biggest bounties.

Revelation War: The Coming Struggle for the Holy Land is a near-future what-if that presumes the US continues its zigzag withdrawal from imperium into neo-isolation, leaving Israel alone to face a hostile coalition of Islamist nations plus Chinese and Russian ‘expeditionary forces.’

There’s one large-hex 34x22” map, at 7.5 miles per hex, along with one sheet of 176 large-size (5/8”) NATO-style counters. Each of the seven turns equals one day of ‘real time.’

Playing time is about two to three hours and, though designed for two-players, it can easily be adapted for solitaire use.
Monopoly with Deadpool theming and game pieces.

Air Flix is a fast paced, Second World War, dexterity based dog fighting game for 2 or more players. In an all-action battle of strategy & skill, you will need to outwit and out-flick your opponents to achieve total aerial dominance!

Develop the skills and learn all the tricks to handling your planes with the flare of a true wartime ace. Swoop in behind your enemies for massive firing bonuses, protect your six with cloud cover & tactial maneuvers.

Slick, intuitive game play, multiple game modes & variants combined with components of the highest possible standard, make this the perfect action dog fighting game for both hardened wargamers & casual players alike.

—description from the publisher

Play cards in sequence of the days of a week, the first player to get rid of their hand wins.
There are two types of cards, one has a date printed on both sides of the card, and the other has only one date printed. 
Players can predict their opponents hand with double printed cards, enabling them to block them from playing those cards.

In this game you try to stack cards without having to take any.
If you have to take cards twice then you are out of the game. The player with the fewest cards taken at the end is the winner.

However, if a player manages to take more than 15 cards, they also win.

Fight epic space battles across the Elite: Dangerous galaxy. Battle in asteroid belts to gain cover against enemy attacks, explore planets to gain advantage over your foe, or send a fleet of transports to construct an unstoppable capital ship. Create an armada of spaceships, fighters, warships – even entire space stations. Use special abilities to outflank your enemy, upgrade your vessels with enhanced equipment or play action cards to save yours ships or foil your opponent.

—description from the publisher

The Starter Pack contains two decks of 30 cards each along with the basic mission cards needed to play any game of ED Battle Cards. All the cards are non-randomised (as they are in every set). For the Starter Pack one deck has mostly Federation aligned ships and the other mostly Imperial.

The players can chose their way. On some spaces, event cards have to be drawn, which benefit or hinder the player.

Seas of peril you’ve crossed, fighting monsters and men, to set foot on the fabled Black Skull island. There’s just one problem: you’re not alone. In fact, it seems that everyone and their parrot are already here!

Black Skull Island is a game of pirate intrigue for 2 to 9 treasure hunting sea wolves, ready to fill their pockets with pure gold!
- Play each fast-paced, crazy struggle for treasure in under 15 minutes!
- Make smart use of 16 unique characters.
- Play a wild party game with up to 9 players!

Black Skull Island is a wild pirate adventure which plays fast enough to fit in your lunch break, but packs enough of punch to entertain a group of friends for a whole night!

Black Skull Island is played over a number of rounds. Every round, each player will play a Character Card (or two, if you are playing a 2-player game) face down on the table. When everyone has chosen which Characters to play, all Character Cards are flipped face-up, and their special abilities are resolved in the order of their respective Activation Numbers (the lowest numbered card is resolved first). After resolving all Character abilities, each player takes back the Character or Characters still in front of them. If at that point any player has 7 or more Booty Cards in front of them, the game ends, and Booty is counted to see who wins.

It’s lunch time, and a most unusual company has arrived! Some are tall, some are short, some have scales for hair or tentacles for feet — but all of them are really, really hungry. Can you fill their bellies before anyone else beats you to tea?

Little Monster That Came For Lunch And Stayed For Tea is a light racing game in which playing your cards right and using the abilities of your two unique monsters makes for a very tasty difference! Each game you are assigned two unique little monsters to feed as quickly as you can as you race against one, two or three opponents. Each little monster has its own special skill, and you want to combo these skills and card abilities to create awesome combos.

On your turn, you either play or draw cards. If you play, you create combos that will move your monsters forward, pushing the opponents' critters backwards! You win the game as soon as both of your monsters reach the end of the table, so eat up!

item.description:
Repel Boarders is a co-operative game for 2 to 6 players, you can take control of any number of the crew under Cpt Frank Smith in either one of the 9 included missions or if you prefer you can design your own! Although it’s not necessary to play the missions in order, should players wish to do so, a short narrative campaign is included in the game.

Gain weapons and armour from the chests scattered about the rooms on-board in your attempt to defeat the forces of space pirates that are attacking your ship. Missions have different objectives ranging from simply surviving a massive rush of pirates or escorting a VIP, to securing and defending vital parts of your ship.

Do you take on the role of a marine and attack the enemy head on or the role of medic or engineer and assist your fellow players in staying alive as wave after wave of blood thirsty pirates swarm the ship. Maybe you are the voice of command and as captain organise the others to follow you. Perhaps you want nothing more than 2 really big guns and a singular purpose and take the role of the robot. Maybe you are stealthy and tactical and can take on the pirates with nothing more than a chefs cleaver?

Each crew character starts with 3 action points which they can then spend freely on either moving, combat (melee or ranged) or on a special action, though only one special action maybe completed per person per turn. Special actions include healing, repairing doors, searching chests and trading etc.

Characters gain further actions and special abilities as the "Alert Level" on-board ship increases. While players start with a modicum of gear as play progresses they may pick up and trade items to suit either their own play style or that of the persona of the crew member they are playing.

Want to design your own campaign where you keep the items on your character and progress through your own customer scenarios? This is entirely possible with Repel Boarders modular double sided game tiles, corridor tiles and board connectors.

-description from publisher

Think you’re meaty enough to take on this Super Sized Sausage?! Switch him on and wait for his commands but be warned you’ll need to be fast to keep up! With 10 grillin’ games and 5 sizzlin’ actions – Twist ME, Shake ME, Dip ME, Stretch ME & Poke ME!

Play him solo or multi play with family and friends. Everyone’s a ‘Wiener’ with Silly Sausage!

—description from the publisher

The winner is determined by whoever scores the highest or the last player standing depending on the game mode you choose.

Items needed:

 1 deck standard playing cards
 Two 6-sided dice




Gameplay:
Each player will choose one suit of cards as their army then roll the die to determine who has the first turn. Each player then draws 3 cards from his deck and places his remaining cards aside. The person to win the first turn of the first round chooses an opponent from among the remaining players. To attack, he lays down one of his three chosen cards. The chosen opponent also lays down one of his three chosen cards.(Right before each player lays down his attacking card,it is best to snap the attacking card out of one’s own hand in a showy and extravagant manner. This is done to intimidate the other player. It is also quite enjoyable.)To determine the winner of the attack, each player must roll a die, combine that number with the value of his card, and whomever has the highest overall score wins the battle. Each number card is worth its face value (the Ace is worth 1 point, the 2 is worth 2 points, etc,), and each face card is worth 10 points. However, when attacking with a Jack, the Jack gains one offensive point becoming worth 11 points, and when defending with a Queen, the Queen gains 1 defensive point becoming worth 11 points. If a tie takes place, the defender wins the round. Play continues in clock-wise fashion with each player attacking only once each round. If a player has no cards when it is his turn to attack, then he is out for the remainder of the round.

Each successive round is begun by the person clock-wise from the person to attack first in the previous round.

The winner of the game is determined by the player with the last King left alive. If a player loses a King during game play, he may continue playing but cannot win the game.

Suit powers

Hearts: Healers. At the end of each turn roll 1 die for any one card that fought during that turn. If the roll is odd, healing failed and proceed to next card or end turn. If even, roll die and regain health up to number rolled or max health (whichever comes first)

Spades: Necromancers. At the end of each turn, if any cards 1-6 “died" during that turn or in a previous turn they are eligible to be revived. Roll a die and revive any eligible card covered by the die. Example: If a 1 is rolled then an the ace (if eligible) can be revived. If a 5 is rolled, any card 1-5 that is eligible can be revived.

Diamonds: +Defense every card. +1 health and 50/50 chance to “block” an attack by rolling die when attacked. If even, a "block" happens and negates an additional damage point.

Clubs: +Offense every card. +1 to attack roll and 50/50 chance to do “double damage” on an attack by rolling die when attacking. If even, a "double damage" happens and adds an additional damage point.

—description from the designer

The new World War is devastating everything with atomic bombs, and due to that, the Government has come to a solution: building better cities over the ruins of the destroyed ones. It is up to the Emergency City Reconstruction companies to do that job and guarantee that these new cities represent the glory of the winning countries over their enemies.

In New Eden Project, players will create projects for a glorious city, participating in the contest to be the chosen company to build the "New Eden", a city that will take place of an enemy capital. By using city part cards in a tile-placement mechanic, they will have to build the project always paying attention to the Contest Requirements, sorted at the beginning of the match.

There are 3 game modes: Populist (using sorted Contest Requirements, one of each of the types A, B, and C), Military (using all of the D Contest Requirements), or Elite (using both previous requirements). These requirement cards are the ones that tell the player how they are going to score in that match.

Regardless of the game mode, the game flow is always the same: players have 1 phase to buy cards using inspiration points (always 5 at the beginning of the phase), and 1 phase to place them in their projects (put them on the table). This continues until someone projects the 10th city part card, triggering the end of the game, when players check the Contest Requirements to see which cards have scored, and how many set-collection points they have won.

-description from designer

item.description:
Camping With Sasquatch is a light card game with a ROAR! Literally. Play cards to complete sets. Sets = Points. Points = Sweet, sweet victory. Sets can either be three of the same card, or three different cards of that suit.

But watch out for that wild Sasquatch! Sasquatch can help you complete a set or you can play Sasquatch on your opponents. Rush to slap down the right card to avoid getting stuck with the elusive Sasquatch!

Camping with Sasquatch is a quick-paced, strategic card game that combines elements of rummy and slapjack. But you decide, will you play nice or will you turn the Sasquatch loose on your friends?

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Ever been with a group of people and can't decide what to eat for dinner? What's For Dinner? is a light and fast game designed to cleanse the palate, inspire hungry players, and bring friends and family to the table. Grab meals that match your cravings and traits before other players snatch them, or you might go without.

Each player is dealt three dining trait cards, discards one card, keeps one hidden, and reveals the third for all players to know what their eating trait is, e.g., vegetarian.

The game comes with a custom food die that represents all food groups: fruit/veggie/meat/dairy/wheat as well as bacon [fats & oils]. Bacon is a wild in the game, representing any of the five basic food groups as the player chooses. Each player rolls the food die during their turn to see what they crave during the round, then either acquire a matching meal card in play from the meal card pyramid of five community meal cards, or veto a specific meal card and discard that card into the dumpster (the bottom of the game box), then draw a wallet card. Wallet cards can be used during the game to purchase a corresponding meal card, better their turn, or impact another player's turn.

The goal of the game is to get the most meal points as others decide to go along with your food choice. The game-end is triggered when the last meal card is drawn from the meal card draw pile.

—description from the publisher

In this game you must do your own groceries! You must see which things you need, and which things you don't. Players will learn that some things are more expensive than others.

Player must roll a die and move their Sesame Street character the rolled amount of steps towards any direction. When the players lands on a coin, they receive one Sesame coin. If they land on a store, they get the chance to buy one item of their shopping list using their collected Sesame coins.

The player who has crossed off all the items of their shopping list wins the game!
